question.title: Can I get the Eclipse Java Formatter to properly handle variable declarator lists
question.body:
Whenever, and only whenever, I have multiple field declarators in a list, I want this style:

private static final String
    CONSTANT_STRING_1 = "foobar",
    CONSTANT_STRING_2 = "foobaz";

That way, I don't have to scan multiple copies of the access level, type, finality, volatility, etc. to know they are all the same. I feel like there used to be a way.

Now, no matter what setting I try, the closest I can get is this output:

private static final String CONSTANT_STRING_1 = "foobar",
CONSTANT_STRING_2 = "foobaz";

question_comments.body: I'm only guessing but maybe you could write a plugin that would format your code how you like. Currently Ctrl+Shift+F formats selected text according to the formatter that you configure in the Eclipse IDE preferences. So maybe you could write a plugin that formats selected code for some combination of keyboard keys.
It does seem strange that you cannot get the formatter at least to indent the second line.

Re: "the above is the easiest possible thing to read" -- whether all the types and qualifiers of a bunch of declarations are the same is rarely the information I want to be most readily accessible. Instead, I almost always want to know what the type and qualifiers are for one or more particular declarations, and for that, I want each declaration to declare exactly one identifier. That's what's easiest for me to read. Because I don't think that's where you intend to focus, I have edited the question to reduce the likelihood of a (further) diversion in that direction.
